perturbation.original_text:
20.	CONFIDENTIALITY 

20.1	Confidentiality obligations 
Unless otherwise provided in this Agreement, any Confidential Information released by either of the Parties (the “Disclosing Party”) to the other Party (the “Receiving Party”) shall not be released in whole or in part to any third party.
perturbation.changed_text:
20.	CONFIDENTIALITY 

20.1	Confidentiality obligations 
Unless otherwise provided in this Agreement, any Confidential Information released by either of the Parties (the “Disclosing Party”) to the other Party (the “Receiving Party”) may be released in whole or in part to any third party, subject to the receiving party's approval.
perturbation.explanation: This modification creates a direct contradiction. The original text strictly prohibits the release of confidential information to third parties. The revised text permits such release, contingent upon the receiving party's approval. This introduces uncertainty regarding the confidentiality obligations, as the receiving party now has the discretion to override the general prohibition.

perturbation.original_text:
13.	SECURITY DEPOSIT 

13.5 At	the maximum at the end of the period of [*****] following the Term, (or such early date as the Company has made all payments due hereunder at the Repairer satisfaction), and provided that the Company is not in Default under this Agreement or any other agreement entered into between the Parties, the Repairer shall pay to the Company an amount equal to the balance of the Security Deposit, if any.
perturbation.changed_text:
13.	SECURITY DEPOSIT 

13.5 At	the maximum at the end of the period of [*****] following the Term, (or such early date as the Company has made all payments due hereunder at the Repairer satisfaction), even if the Company is in Default under this Agreement or any other agreement entered into between the Parties, the Repairer shall pay to the Company an amount equal to the balance of the Security Deposit, if any.
perturbation.explanation: This is internal contradiction because the original text states the Repairer will pay the balance of the security deposit if the Company is NOT in default while the new text is stating that the Repairer will pay the balance even if the company is in default. This will create uncertainty in the enforcement.

perturbation.original_text:
3.1
The Agreement enters into force on the Signing Date; it will have a duration of [*****] as from the Start Date (the “Initial Term”).
perturbation.changed_text:
3.1
The Agreement enters into force on the Signing Date; it will have a duration of [*****] as from the Start Date (the “Initial Term”), but it may end prematurely at either party's discretion.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mentions that the agreement duration is pre-defined as the initial term, but the changed text adds the possibility of prematurely ending the agreement, which contradicts the prior statement that it will run a specific duration.
